awd_titl_txt: Light-Directed Synthesis of Metal Nanocrystal Dimers for Scalable Precision Plasmonics
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program in the Division of Chemistry, Dr. Matthew Law at the University of California, Irvine is developing methods to link pairs of metal nanoparticles together to form dimers. The small gap between the nanoparticles can concentrate light, which could provide significant technological impact. However, scientists still lack good syntheses for making them. Working with his students, Dr. Law is using light to protect the nanoparticle pairs as they form in a solution. This method aims to produce dimers with higher purity, better control over structure and in larger quantities than is possible using existing methods. These fundamental studies could lead to better catalysts and chemical sensors, and new biomedical applications of these nanoparticles in the long term. The project also promotes STEM education and provides academic opportunities and enrichment to low-income students from backgrounds with historically low levels of participation in higher education.
    
Colloidal plasmonic metal nanocrystals (NCs) that possess strong and tunable localized surface plasmon resonances (LSPRs) in the visible and near-infrared regions of the spectrum (e.g., gold and silver NCs) are of great interest for fundamental studies of light-matter interactions. This project is developing a novel light-directed method for the one-pot, scalable synthesis of mono-disperse, tunable, and functional metal NC dimers that promises to overcome the limitations of previous approaches.  The synthesis is monitored by in situ and ex situ absorption spectroscopy and ex situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The resulting NC dimers are expected to have excellent structural mono-dispersity and stability, tunable and accessible hot spots, and other characteristics that make them well-suited for accelerating progress in plasmonic chemistry and physics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For the past few decades, scientists have been attempting to link nanocrystals (tiny crystals) together to make “nanocrystal molecules,” similar to real molecules that are made by linking together individual atoms. Nanocrystal molecules built from metal, semiconductor, or magnetic nanocrystals are expected to have new and exciting properties that could enable new technologies. However, scientists still lack good syntheses for making even the simplest nanocrystal molecules, including nanocrystal dimers (linked pairs of nanocrystals). In this project, researchers at the University of California, Irvine (UCI) worked to develop a new way to make metal nanocrystal dimers using light. Their idea is to use light from a laser to protect dimers as they form in a solution. This new method promises to produce dimers with higher purity, better control over structure, and in much larger amounts than possible using existing methods. The availability of uniform, high-quality dimers would benefit researchers around the world who work to develop better catalysts, chemical sensors, and cancer treatments. The researchers successfully demonstrated how to control the rate at which nanocrystals link together to form dimers and other small nanocrystal molecules by tuning the “stickiness” of the nanocrystals and the amount of salt and protons in the solution. Three of the six candidate molecules evaluated by the project were found to protect the dimers as they form. The research established that illuminating the dimers with laser light of the correct wavelength can indeed stop – and even reverse – the aggregation of the nanocrystals. Future work will focus on refining this light-driven process to produce pure nanocrystal dimers. The project also promoted STEM education and provided academic opportunities and enrichment to low-income students from backgrounds with historically low levels of participation in higher education. Approximately thirty middle school students from underserved communities participated in hands-on experiments to understand the synthesis of metal nanocrystals and how such nanocrystals absorb and scatter light. Four Ph.D. students received fundamental training and experience in nanocrystal synthesis, assembly and surface chemistry, materials characterization, spectroscopy, and laser systems. Two of these students earned their Ph.D. degrees and are now working for U.S. semiconductor and pharmaceutical companies. Several undergraduate students also participated in the research and are now enrolled in Ph.D. programs at top U.S. universities.
